Gravity is not just the attraction between objects and the Earth. It is an attraction that exists between all objects with mass, everywhere in the universe. That is why things fly away when they are propelled upward with more force than gravity exerts. They are then no longer under the influence of the gravitational pull of the Earth because they have moved to a place where its effect is weaker, or they are not under the direct effect of the gravitational pull of the Earth at all.

Gravity is a force that pulls things together. It is an invisible force that attracts objects towards each other. The scientist Sir Isaac Newton described gravity as a result of universal attraction, claiming that gravity is the force that attracts all physical bodies toward each other. This force governs the movement of bodies including that of our planet, Earth. It is this force that keeps the planets in orbit around the sun and prevents objects from drifting off into space. 

Here is an example to help you better understand this concept. Consider a ball and a basket. The ball represents the Earth and the basket represents the Sun. Now, let's pretend that we place the ball in the basket. We gently give the ball a slight push towards the basket. The ball then begins to move towards the basket, demonstrating the pull of gravity. 

This force is also responsible for the phenomenon of gravity on Earth, which is why objects fall to the ground when dropped. This phenomenon, the result of the weightiness of matter, is represented by the attraction of the Earth for smaller bodies and that of the Sun for planets.
